title: Society of Professional Accountants of Canada
text:
The Society of Professional Accountants of Canada (SPAC) is a <a href="professional%20association">professional association</a> established in <a href="Canada">Canada</a>. The SPAC mandate is to set standards for qualification and <a href="continuing%20education">continuing education</a> to ensure a professional standard for members. The SPAC is composed of both Canadian and international members. <a href="Small%20and%20medium-sized%20enterprises">Small and medium-sized enterprises</a> are the <a href="Market%20segmentation">market segment</a> targeted by the SPAC to provide their services.
History.
The "Canadian Institute of Accredited Public Accountants" (CIAPA) was founded in 1938. On May 7, 1946, the CIAPA was granted <a href="letters%20patent">letters patent</a> under the provisions of Part II of the "Canada Corporations Act", which was subsequently replaced by the "Canada Not-for-profit Corporations Act" in 2009. The CIAPA is now under the control of the SPAC.
RPA and APA designations.
The <a href="Registered%20Professional%20Accountant">Registered Professional Accountant</a> (RPA) designation is granted by the SPAC to members that have completed <a href="List%20of%20universities%20in%20Canada">university</a> or <a href="College%20%28Canada%29">college</a> courses set by SPAC, achieved two-years of work <a href="internship">experience</a> and passed the four Mandatory Professional Exams (MPE): <a href="Financial%20Accounting">Financial Accounting</a>, <a href="Management%20Accounting">Management Accounting</a>, <a href="Analytics">Data Analytics and Technology</a> and <a href="Taxation">Taxation</a>.
In addition, the SPAC issues the Accredited Professional Accountant (APA) to members holding the RPA designation for over ten years. RPA and APA designated accountants with a Professional Practice Certification (PPC) are qualified to issue Canadian Standards on Related Services 4200 (CSRS 4200) compilation engagements in professional practice.
RPA and APA's are not permitted to perform <a href="assurance%20services">assurance services</a> including review or audit engagements. These designations are not historically as well known as the <a href="Chartered%20Professional%20Accountants%20of%20Canada">Chartered Professional Accountants of Canada</a>. Since the 2014 unification of the <a href="Chartered%20Professional%20Accountant">Chartered Professional Accountant</a>s (CPA), the RPA designation serves as a small business focused accounting body positioning itself to service the market space the <a href="Certified%20General%20Accountant">Certified General Accountant</a> (CGA) designation formerly addressed.
